Problem:
A complex function is defined as \\( z(t) = e^{i \omega t} \), where \\( \omega \\) is a constant frequency. We analyze the effects of a linear transformation \\( L(z) = cz + d \\) over time t, where c and d are complex constants.

If the transformation \\( L(z) \\) is applied to the function \\( z(t) \\) at t = 0 and allowed to evolve naturally, will \\( L(z(t)) \\) at any time t > 0 be equivalent to the direct evaluation of \\( z(t) \\) under the original function without the transformation?
Explanation: Applying \\( L(z) \\) modifies the initial output of the function by adding a constant and scaling it, changing the trajectory of the solution over time. The transformation changes both amplitude and phase components of the function, resulting in a wave pattern different from the untransformed case.
